prompt: 71F, ref Dr. Ingraham. Recurrent effusion. US showed Right large, Left small. Drained 1400mL Straw-colored fluid from Right 9th ICS. Stopped due to symptoms. No comps.
completion:
NOTE_ID:  note_040 SOURCE_FILE: note_040.txt

INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT

DATE OF PROCEDURE: [Date] CC Referred Physician: Dr. Ingraham

INDICATION FOR OPERATION The patient is a 71-year-old female who presents with Symptomatic Pleural Effusion.

The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to Chest Ultrasound and Thoracentesis were discussed with the patient in detail.

CONSENT Obtained before the procedure. The patient indicated a wish to proceed with the procedure and informed consent was signed.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

Symptomatic Pleural Effusion

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

Symptomatic Pleural Effusion

PROCEDURE

Ultrasound, chest (includes mediastinum), real time with image documentation (Bilateral)

Aspirate pleura with imaging (Thoracentesis)

ANESTHESIA Local ONLY.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS None (implied by complication status).

COMPLICATIONS None.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL

Patient Position: Sitting.

Focused Thoracic Ultrasound (Pleura & Lung) Focused thoracic ultrasound was performed and images were saved and uploaded to the patient's medical record.

Left Chest Findings:

Pleural Effusion: No significant effusion.

Diaphragm: Normal motion.

Lung: Lung sliding was present before and after the procedure. No consolidation or atelectasis was present.

Pleura: Normal.

Right Chest Findings:

Pleural Effusion: Large volume, anechoic echogenicity, with no loculations.

Diaphragm: Normal motion.

Lung: Lung sliding was present before and after the procedure. Consolidation/atelectasis was present.

Pleura: Normal.

Thoracentesis Based on ultrasound evaluation, thoracentesis was determined to be feasible and proceeded as planned.

The insertion site was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. A thoracentesis kit was used.

Anesthesia: 10 mL of Lidocaine 1% was administered.

Entry Site: Right 9th Intercostal Space at the Posterior-axillary line.

Procedure Findings:

Fluid Removed: 1400 mL.

Appearance: Straw-colored.

Notes: Drainage was stopped due to patient reported mild chest discomfort.

Drainage Device: Pleurovac.

Suction: No suction used.

Closure: The site was not sutured.

SPECIMENS Fluid was submitted for the following analyses:

pH

LDH

Glucose

Total Protein

Cholesterol

Cell Count

ADA

Gram Stain/Culture

AFB

Fungal Culture

Cytology

IMPRESSION / PLAN

The patient is a 71-year-old female who presented for Chest Ultrasound and Thoracentesis.

The patient tolerated the procedure well.

There were no immediate complications.

Post-procedure chest x-ray (CXR) ordered.

Follow up pleural studies.

Continued care per primary team.

Disposition: Nursing Unit.

INDICATION FOR OPERATION The patient is a 62-year-old female who presents with Dyspnea secondary to pleural effusion.

The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to Chest Ultrasound and Thoracentesis were discussed with the patient in detail.

Left Chest Findings:

Pleural Effusion: Minimal fluid observed.

Diaphragm: Normal motion.

Lung: Lung sliding was present before and after the procedure. No consolidation or atelectasis was present.

Pleura: Normal.

Right Chest Findings:

Pleural Effusion: Significant volume, hypoechoic, free-flowing fluid.

Diaphragm: Normal motion.

Lung: Lung sliding was present before and after the procedure. Lower lobe consolidation visible.

Pleura: Normal.

Thoracentesis Based on ultrasound evaluation, thoracentesis was determined to be feasible and proceeded as planned.

INDICATION FOR OPERATION The patient is a 62-year-old male who presents with Dyspnea secondary to pleural effusion.

The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to Chest Ultrasound and Thoracentesis were discussed with the patient in detail.

CONSENT Obtained before the procedure. The patient indicated a wish to proceed with the procedure and informed consent was signed.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

Dyspnea secondary to pleural effusion

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

Dyspnea secondary to pleural effusion

PROCEDURE

Ultrasound, chest (includes mediastinum), real time with image documentation (Bilateral)

Aspirate pleura with imaging (Thoracentesis)

ANESTHESIA Local ONLY.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS None (implied by complication status).

COMPLICATIONS None.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL

Patient Position: Sitting.

Focused Thoracic Ultrasound (Pleura & Lung) Focused thoracic ultrasound was performed and images were saved and uploaded to the patient's medical record.

Left Chest Findings:

Pleural Effusion: Large volume, anechoic echogenicity, with no loculations.

Diaphragm: Normal motion.

Lung: Lung sliding was present before and after the procedure. Compressive atelectasis noted.

Pleura: Normal.

Right Chest Findings:

Pleural Effusion: Small volume, anechoic echogenicity, with no loculations.

Diaphragm: Normal motion.

Lung: Lung sliding was present before and after the procedure. No consolidation or atelectasis was present.

Pleura: Normal.

Thoracentesis Based on ultrasound evaluation, thoracentesis was determined to be feasible and proceeded as planned.

The insertion site was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. A thoracentesis kit was used.

Anesthesia: 10 mL of Lidocaine 1% was administered.

Entry Site: Left 9th Intercostal Space at the Posterior-axillary line.

Procedure Findings:

Fluid Removed: 1100 mL.

Appearance: Serous.

Notes: Drainage was stopped due to symptoms (coughing, complaint of dry throat).

Drainage Device: Pleurovac.

Suction: No suction used.

Closure: The site was not sutured.

SPECIMENS Fluid was submitted for the following analyses:

pH

LDH

Glucose

Total Protein

Cholesterol

Cell Count

ADA

Gram Stain/Culture

AFB

Fungal Culture

Cytology

IMPRESSION / PLAN

The patient is a 62-year-old male who presented for Chest Ultrasound and Thoracentesis.

The patient tolerated the procedure well.

There were no immediate complications.

Post-procedure chest x-ray (CXR) ordered.

Follow up pleural studies.

Continued care per primary team.

Disposition: Nursing Unit.

prompt: Procedure: US Chest + Thoracentesis. Patient: 71 F. Dx: Recurrent Effusion. Site: Left 9th ICS. Output: 600 mL Serous. Stopped: therapeutic goal met.
